node.title: Make Fails, Minimal Error Message
node.bodyText:
Bug Description
When I run make on my Ubuntu 22.04.2 machine in the test directory as described here, I get a bunch of file not found errors for moose/libmesh/installed. I suspect this isn't the main error as moose/libmesh is completely empty.
Make eventually spits out the following error:
make: *** [/path_to_moose/moose/framework/build.mk:149: /path_to_moose/moose/framework/build/unity_src/src_Unity..opt.lo] Error 127
Poking around in the .mk file lead me to believe that it would take far too long to fix whatever was causing this error. I don't have any experience in C, so I apologize for any lack of knowledge in advance. I've had a terrible time using make files no matter who the distributor, so it's likely I'm making a very common mistake.
Steps to Reproduce
-Install moose as described by install guide (except instead of ~/projects I used my own directory)
-Run make -j 6
Impact
I can't install moose.

Can we know the directory you are working from? Is it somewhere in your home directory (or somewhere where you always have write permissions without the use of sudo)?
File not found errors during make might be that the Conda environment didn't properly activate. The error, I am guessing was something like this?
❯ make
/bin/sh: /Users/milljm/projects/moose/libmesh/installed/contrib/bin/libmesh-config: No such file or directory
/bin/sh: /Users/milljm/projects/moose/libmesh/installed/contrib/bin/libmesh-config: No such file or directory
/bin/sh: /Users/milljm/projects/moose/libmesh/installed/contrib/bin/libmesh-config: No such file or directory
/bin/sh: /Users/milljm/projects/moose/libmesh/installed/contrib/bin/libmesh-config: No such file or directory
/bin/sh: /Users/milljm/projects/moose/libmesh/installed/contrib/bin/libmesh-config: No such file or directory
/bin/sh: /Users/milljm/projects/moose/libmesh/installed/contrib/bin/libmesh-config: No such file or directory
/bin/sh: /Users/milljm/projects/moose/libmesh/installed/contrib/bin/libmesh-config: No such file or directory
/bin/sh: /Users/milljm/projects/moose/libmesh/installed/contrib/bin/libmesh-config: No such file or directory
/bin/sh: /Users/milljm/projects/moose/libmesh/installed/contrib/bin/libmesh-config: No such file or directory
<trimmed>


❯ echo $LIBMESH_DIR
<nothing returns>

This occurs due to our Make system trying to utilize either $LIBMESH_DIR (which as I demonstrate above does not exist), or use moose/libmesh instead. Which also does not exist when following our Conda instructions (because our Conda instructions eventually lead you to installing a pre-built version of libMesh via moose-dev.
The fix (for my demonstration above), is to activate the moose environment:
❯ mamba activate moose
❯ echo $LIBMESH_DIR
/Users/milljm/mambaforge3/envs/moose/libmesh
I now have LIBMESH_DIR properly available, and so a make will proceed normally.

node.title: Peacock execution aborted (core dumped)
node.bodyText:
Hi I'm trying to learn MOOSE and going through the tutorial. I got to step 2 execute input file
I can execute the input file with :
cd ~/projects/babbler/test/tests/kernels/simple_diffusion
../../../../babbler-opt -i simple_diffusion.i

but I want to be able to run peacock to have a GUI.
I run the execution command in peacock:
cd ~/projects/babbler/test/tests/kernels/simple_diffusion
~/projects/moose/python/peacock/peacock -i simple_diffusion.i

The outputs:
Aborted (core dumped)
What causes this error and how can I resolve it?

Hello
Does peacock start on its own without the input file?
Are you using the moose environment to run peacock or did you make a dedicated moose-peacock environment?
Guillaume

Also what operating system are you using? If using Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL), there are additional steps to follow to allow graphical forwarding to take place (except with Windows 11. I recall Windows 11 WSL has native X11 support. Have not been able to test that personally however).

@GiudGiud I used the peacock environment where my CL shows (peacock).
Is that what you mean by starting peacock without the input file?
@milljm Im using Ubuntu on windows 10. I’ll try the find the GUI instructions.

I think your original post doesn't include the shell prompt, so we were unable to determine if you were using (peacock).
Sorry I didn't list those instructions in my post! I mean these: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/windows.html.

If you made it as far as running tests, I think you've mostly completed the WSL side of the instructions.
Can you perform the following:
mamba deactivate
mamba activate base # this just makes sure we are at the base environment, cleanly.
mamba activate peacock
~/projects/moose/python/peacock/peacock
I want to see if Peacock launches without supplying an input file or not. We can troubleshoot from there...

(base) chris@DESKTOPI: ~$ mamba deactivate
chris@DESKTOP: ~$ mamba activate base
(base) chris@DESKTOP: ~$ mamba activate peacock
(peacock) chris@DESKTOP: ~$ cd ./projects
(peacock) chris@DESKTOP: ~/projects$ ~/projects/moose/python/peacock/peacock
Aborted (core dumped)
(peacock) chris@DESKTOP: ~/projects$

I have installed VcXsrv and WSL installed
(base) chris@DESKTOP:~$ wsl --list --verbose
Unknown command: --list
WSL
Wsman Shell commandLine, version 0.2.1

I am getting the same issue no matter what I try for other VTK applications at the moment. But I think its a MacOS issue. Can you try the following? It is a GUI application which uses many of the same dependencies as Peacock:
mamba deactivate
mamba activate base
mamba create -n paraview paraview
mamba activate paraview
paraview
For me, It loads partially, then unexpectedly dies with the following errors:
$ paraview
(   1.483s) [paraview        ]vtkOpenGLRenderWindow.c:481    ERR| vtkXOpenGLRenderWindow (0x55c134e0ac40): Unable to find a valid OpenGL 3.2 or later implementation. Please update your video card driver to the latest version. If you are using Mesa please make sure you have version 11.2 or later and make sure your driver in Mesa supports OpenGL 3.2 such as llvmpipe or openswr. If you are on windows and using Microsoft remote desktop note that it only supports OpenGL 3.2 with nvidia quadro cards. You can use other remoting software such as nomachine to avoid this issue.
(   1.984s) [paraview        ]vtkOpenGLRenderWindow.c:481    ERR| vtkXOpenGLRenderWindow (0x55c136186650): Unable to find a valid OpenGL 3.2 or later implementation. Please update your video card driver to the latest version. If you are using Mesa please make sure you have version 11.2 or later and make sure your driver in Mesa supports OpenGL 3.2 such as llvmpipe or openswr. If you are on windows and using Microsoft remote desktop note that it only supports OpenGL 3.2 with nvidia quadro cards. You can use other remoting software such as nomachine to avoid this issue.

Loguru caught a signal: SIGSEGV
Stack trace:
0       0x7efdb2ff6b80 /lib64/libc.so.6(+0x4eb80) [0x7efdb2ff6b80]
(   2.009s) [paraview        ]                       :0     FATL| Signal: SIGSEGV
Segmentation fault (core dumped)

I am running on Windows not MAC
(base) chris@DESKTOP:~$ mamba activate paraview
(paraview) chris@DESKTOP:~$ paraview
qt.qpa.xcb: could not connect to display <IP address>
qt.qpa.plugin: Could not load the Qt platform plugin "xcb" in" even though it was found.
This application failed to start because no Qt platform plugin could be initialized. Reinstalling the application may fix this problem.

Available platform plugins are: eglfs, minimal, minimalegl, offscreen, vnc, webgl, xcb.

Aborted (core dumped)
(paraview) chris@DESKTOP:~$

This other discussion on lead me to run this to install xcb in:
pip uninstall opencv-python
pip install opencv-python-headless

Now it's installed but won't initialize
(paraview) chris@DESKTOP:~$ paraview
qt.qpa.xcb: could not connect to display <IP address>
qt.qpa.plugin: Could not load the Qt platform plugin "xcb" in "" even though it was found.
This application failed to start because no Qt platform plugin could be initialized. Reinstalling the application may fix this problem.

Available platform plugins are: eglfs, minimal, minimalegl, offscreen, vnc, webgl, xcb.

The paraview error about not being able to connect to your DISPLAY, may be due to not having it set in your ~/.bashrc... We have instructions for setting this, such as:
echo "export DISPLAY=$(cat /etc/resolv.conf | grep nameserver | awk '{print $2}'):0.0" >> ~/.bashrc
Before you do this, can you verify if the above is already there?
I am asking my lab for a Windows machine in order to troubleshoot this issue. This could take some time...

node.title: Periodic Boundary condition for 3D mesh
node.bodyText:
For 2D mesh, I would use 'auto direction = x' or 'y'. But or 3D mesh, for repeating, I need to add periodic BC along plane. Could anyone provide me the format of doing that?
Thanks in advance.

Hello
In 3D, it s the same syntax. The auto_direction can be x, y or z.
No other automatic detection of periodicity in a given direction is supported.
Guillaume

node.title: read an external file
node.bodyText:
Hello!
I want to read some materials properties from an external file (.txt, .cvs), like young_modulus and poisson_ratio, and add them to the material modulus.  Is it possible?
And a second question, if I have a file with strain-stress information, (this could be a plot of a strain-stress relation for a material)
Can a read a specific strain and take the corresponding stress?

Hello
It's definitely possible.
You ll want to use this object for computing the elasticity tensor from variable (material properties) young modulus and poisson ratio
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/ComputeVariableIsotropicElasticityTensor.html
To read material properties from CSV, we need more details. How are they tabulated in that file? As a function of space? Temperature?
I dont think we can do the second thing. @hugary1995 will know for sure
Guillaume
I will read it as a function of space

You can load CSVs for space-dependent profiles using this object:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/functions/PiecewiseConstantFromCSV.html
This will create a function. Then you can use this object to make it (them) materials:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/GenericFunctionMaterial.html

node.title: can material object receive properties from non-material objects
node.bodyText:
Hi All,
In Materials System, Material objects produce properties and other objects (including materials) consume these properties. Is it possible to input variable values calculated in the other objects such Interfacekernels or BCs objects into a Material object?
Please help.  S. Thomas

Hello
typically not. BCs and interface kernels are consumers of properties and variables, not producers
you should look to move the computation of the quantities you care about to materials.
Which quantities are you trying to compute in a BC / InterfaceKernel?
Guillaume

 fi;

Thanks a lot!

Did you recursively reinit all submodules though?
Eigen needs to be updated here, and it s a submodule of a submodule (libmesh) of MOOSE
Yes. My local libmesh is now updated to version 1.8.0-pre. The commit hash of my local libmesh is 482ca36. This matches the latest commit on offcial moose.
It s not just libmesh. You need to make sure the libmesh submodule s (eigen!) are also up to date. This is why we are asking for a recursive submodule update

This is the command I used: git submodule update --init --recursive. I ran it in my git clone dir. I think that should recursively reinit all submodule. I did not see another update command on MOOSE webpage.

GCC 11 is pretty new; you might want to try compiling without -Werror. -Because it looks like we're stopping on warnings only at this point (to my eyes).
Our continuous integration system is performing builds/tests using GCC 9.4.x (and 10.x when using Conda).
It wouldn't be that hard for me to bump a version up on one of our builds, see what happens. I'll report back if I can reproduce a failure using GCC 11.3.

node.title: ./update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh and ./update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh failed
node.bodyText:
I build PETSc and libmesh according to the instruction in the file 'faq_build_petsc.md' (you can find this file in your moose folder)

but when I run  ./update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh, it failed:

and then when I run ./update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh, it failed:

how can I build PETSc and libmesh?

Hello
Please follow these instructions:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/hpc_install_moose.html
If petsc install fails, there is no point trying to install libmesh. Petsc is needed there
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume
Thank you for reply
According to the instructions: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/hpc_install_moose.html
I found maybe the only thing I missed was that I did not install CMake

There are two ways you can accomplish this; Install only the necessary conda packages in order to require the need for you building petsc and libmesh (thus not colliding with the petsc and libmesh installed packages), or building the whole stack from scratch by following these instructions: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/manual_installation_gcc.html
The easier solution is to go the Conda route:
mamba activate base
mamba create -n compilers moose-mpich cmake
mamba activate compilers
From this environment, you are safe to run the two scripts which build PETSc and libMesh:
export METHODS=dbg METHOD=dbg  # debug mode, as I assume you are wanting to use gdb
export MOOSE_JOBS=8            # or how ever many cores your machine is capable of
cd moose/scripts
./update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh
./update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh
You should probably clean up any old builds of MOOSE before following these steps...

node.title: Global strain method with input mesh with tetrahedra elements giving zero solution despite of applied stress
node.bodyText:
I tried to apply the global strain method with periodic boundary conditions based on the paper by @SudiptaBiswas
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0168874X20301165
I have an .inp mesh file and I copied the input file example global_strain_uniaxial.i
from the tensor mechanics module.
The example works well of course, and the only change I made is using the FileMeshGenerator at the beginning
instead of GeneratedMeshGenerator.
Then I define periodic boundary conditions using the node sets in the .inp file and translation vectors
instead of the original auto_direction.
Relevant input files are here:
https://github.com/ngrilli/c_pfor_am/tree/main/test/tests/GlobalStrain
When I run the simulation I get a result with zero displacements and there is no deformation
even though I would expect it because of the applied stress.
What could be the problem?
The only differences I can notice with respect to the working examples are:


I am using linear tetrahedra elements instead of hexahedra.


The nodes on my periodic surfaces do not match spatially, but I thought MOOSE has the capability to handle this
and I am not getting any error anyway.


Thank you very much in advance for your help,
Best Regards,
Nicolò
PBC nodesets have to be conformal. There has been some recent development on weak enforcement of PBC. Though I'm not sure what's the current status of that. @lindsayad

@hugary1995  thank you very much for the answer. I will try matching the nodes on the periodic surfaces.
Indeed I am very interested in using weak enforcements if that allows me to progress with the current mesh.

node.title: Iterative problem
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone
I am trying to build an app that implements the procedure to calculate the SPH factors described in https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0306454919300040 .
For the solution aspect, https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0306454917303079 is also useful.
My question is, what MOOSE features are best for this purpose?
The procedure is based on iterations in which the multigroup neutron diffusion equation is solved, and then the obtained flux and current values are used to calculate corrective factors for material properties and boundary conditions, and possible source terms with which to solve it again, until convergence of the factors.
Is it possible to achieve this simply using actions, by having an action that adds problems until convergence?
Should I use "MultiApps" with a single subapplication?
Can a ReferenceResidualProblem work instead?
Thanks for your time
Gabriele
@vincentlaboure @YaqiWang @snschune do you guys want to weigh-in here?

I would recommend setting this up either as an optimization problem with the optimization module https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/optimization/index.html
Or just do fixed point iterations and use a parametric study from the stochastic tools module
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/ParameterStudy/index.html
For very large SPH factor problems, there is large scale more complex machinery in Griffin to compute the SPH factors (I can find the paper if needed).
I have used successfully fixed point iterations to get SPH factors with OpenMOC.
How many factors are you trying to determine?

The approach described in https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0306454919300040 is relatively straightforward to perform in MOOSE as the equivalence (SPH, DF or SPH-DF) problem is recast into a steady-state source-free Newton formulation. In Griffin (previously, in Rattlesnake), we then just use a Steady executioner and solve for the fluxes (which the SPH or discontinuity factors are a by-product of).
For more complicated problems with tough convergence, it can be useful to first perform a few traditional SPH iterations (as described in Section 2.2.1 of https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0306454917303079) to provide a good initial guess. Griffin has a dedicated solver to do that is fairly close to a Steady executioner.

Hello
you can pass a PostprocessorName then use the getPostprocessorValueByName routine and store this in a reference (that part is really important)
Guillaume

also <RealEigenVector> isnt what's usually used for vector. We use std::vector<Real>.
Finally, are you writing the equations in terms of the SPH factors being the nonlinear variables?
Because otherwise I don't see how this is SPH-PJFNK

The approach (which is necessary unless I misunderstood how SPH-PJFNK is implemented in MOOSE) was to insert the SPH factors in the material property evaluation.
So for a given material, instead of it producing a cross section property Sigma, I wanted to have it produce a property mu*Sigma, where mu is the SPH factor, calculated as mu = (phi_ref)/(phi).
Clearly, to do so the material would have had to take as parameters the reference fluxes, the flux array variable itself, and possibly a postprocessor with which to perform the integrals (although maybe it would have worked better to just instantiate a postprocessor as an attribute of the material object).
To my understanding, this would have resulted in the material property being recalculated (i.e. the residual matrix being reassembled) at all linear/nonlinear steps while solving for the flux (hence the question about the matrix used for the Krylov spaces).
This is what I assumed @vincentlaboure meant when talking about a steady-state source free reformulation (in that all terms of the equations would be brought to the left hand side, instead of first building the source as in traditional SPH, and the problem itself would be just a (nonlinear, because of the dependence of the material properties on the flux) steady one).
This might all be nonsense to be frank, I am dealing with a lot of black boxes here.
For instance I don't know if it possible to have a postprocessor calculate an integral at every iteration of the solver.
The fact that properties are recalculated at every calculation step I got from the "material system" page on the MOOSE site:
"The properties are produced on demand, thus the computed values are always up to date. For example, a property that relies on a solution variable (e.g., thermal conductivity as function of temperature) will be computed with the current temperature during the solve iterations, so the properties are tightly coupled."
The overall approach is what I gathered from the "Algorithm 2" box in https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0306454917303079
I should mention that I only wanted to apply this to problems with vacuum boundary, so no normalization was required.
I also didn't insert all necessary physical properties in the example I provided, just diffusivity and removal cross-section for simplicity, but clearly the real thing should also have the other parameters appearing in the multigroup diffusion equation.

For instance I don't know if it possible to have a postprocessor calculate an integral at every iteration of the solver.

See the execute_on parameter of the postprocessor. It s set by default to end of the timestep for execution, but you can make it be on linear or nonlinear iterations

To my understanding, this would have resulted in the material property being recalculated (i.e. the residual matrix being reassembled) at all linear/nonlinear steps

This is the default as well for PJFNK / Newton.

This might all be nonsense to be frank, I am dealing with a lot of black boxes here.

I think your understanding is pretty good. The nonlinear variables are indeed the fluxes (which is equivalent to solving for the SPH factors but with the advantage of having a very similar formulation when we compute and use the SPH factors).
Regarding your implementation, I'm sure you can make it work that way but the trickiest part of the implementation is to make sure you can keep track of which reference flux goes to which part of the domain (at least if you are targeting large problems with lots of SPH regions). We use an extra element integer in the mesh to do that. Then you can have a single ElementUserObject performing the flux integration at each linear iteration over all the SPH regions.

The postprocessors or the ElementUserObject performing the integration of fluxes on SPH regions can have execute_on parameter equal to linear or nonlinear as said by @GiudGiud. In the former, cross sections depends on SPH factors which depends on flux, thus we introduce nonlinearity in the residual evaluation, PJFNK is using Newton iteration to solve this nonlinear problem. In the later, Newton iteration is equivalent with SPH iteration, i.e. at each iteration or linear solve, SPH factors are fixed. If you do need to evaluate discontinuity factors on vacuum boundaries, you may want to consider using DomainUserObject so that you can put volumetric flux integration and surface partial current integration in one place. Wish you a success on this implementation.

Many thanks to all of you for your advice.
I have managed to put together what I think is a basic working version, about which I have a few more questions:
-For the postprocessors, I have been using   execute_on = 'LINEAR NONLINEAR' because it seems to me to do what is described in the paper. Is this correct?
-I was not sure on how to go about implementing an initial source for the first iteration (like in the paper), so to avoid getting a trivial solution I decided to simply set an initial condition for the variable as a constant equal to the average flux over the whole geometry, like:
[Variables]
[./flux]
    type = ArrayMooseVariable
    components = 2
    initial_condition = '1.5 1.5'
[../]
[]

Am I correct in assuming that this sets the all the FE coefficients for the first PJFNK iteration to 1.5?
Is there any more sensible way to do this, for instance using a finite element interpolation of a piecewise constant function that is equal to the average flux on the various homogenized zones (which for me coincide with material blocks)?
I looked at the function system but I haven't found much.
-I have been using RealEigenVector and RealEigenMatrix as types for the material properties because it is more convenient for manipulations, e.g.:
   _chi_nu_sigma_f[_qp]    = (1/_k_ref)*_v_chi.array()* (_v_nu_sigma_f.array()*sph_factors.array()).transpose();
  
for (int j =0;  j< _v_diffusivity.size(); j++)
  {
      _sigma_s[_qp].row(j)    = (_v_sigma_s.row(j).array())*sph_factors.array();
  }


Is there any reason not to do this?
-I can calculate the sph factors from the reference fluxes and the postprocessor values, but it would be nice if there was an ArrayMaterialPropertyIntegralPostprocessor like the one to integrate array variables.
If I want that I have to code it myself right?

For the postprocessors, I have been using  execute_on = 'LINEAR NONLINEAR'

Typically just having linear is ok. I assume that having an extra evaluation at the beginning of each Newton iteration does not change things.

Am I correct in assuming that this sets the all the FE coefficients for the first PJFNK iteration to 1.5?

It does set the initial values to the flux variables. The meaning of FE coefficients depends on the shape function family. For LAGRANGE, yes, all coefficients will be the values at the nodes, thus equal to 1.5. You can implement your own InitialCondition to use the reference flux to initialize the flux in a more sensible way. Or you can start from the simple initialization with few SPH iterations.

Is there any reason not to do this?

You can use gperftools (MOOSE has a documentation page on how to do it) to do some profiling if performance is a concern. But I doubt this can cause issue.

If I want that I have to code it myself right?

Yes, if it is missing in MOOSE. But if you think that can be generally useful and can be maintained in framework, please feel free to contribute by sending in a pull request to MOOSE repository on github.

I now have an implementation of PJFNK-SPH-DF that works for very simple problems, but doesn't seem to converge for a more complicated one, and I would like to try to add the traditional sph iterations at the beginning.
Is this best accomplished by using stateful material properties on the source terms?
I am now using ArrayConstantICs to initialize the flux to its average value on the homogenized zone. Is this likely to be too coarse?
Should the vacuum BC term be part of the source in the picard iteration?
Thanks again
Gabriele

node.title: Spatially dependent coefficient of thermal expansion (CTE) for calculating eigen strain
node.bodyText:
Following the discussion in , #21785, which considers temperature dependent CTE, I was wondering whether I can also pass this material property as a function of space, for example linearly varying with coordinate 'z'.
To do this I tried the following:
[Materials]
  [./elasticity_tensor]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = 150e6
    poissons_ratio = 0.3
  [../]
  [./small_stress]
    type = ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress
  [../]
  
  [./thermal_expansion_strain]
    type = ComputeInstantaneousThermalExpansionFunctionEigenstrain
    thermal_expansion_function = cte_func_inst
    stress_free_temperature = 0.0
    temperature = temp
    eigenstrain_name = eigenstrain
  [../]
[]

[Functions]

  [./cte_func_inst]
    type = ParsedFunction
    value = '1e-4*(z+1)'
  [../]

  [./temp_function]
    type  = ParsedFunction
    value = 100.0
  [../]
 
[]

But I don't see any difference in the eigenstrain, most likely because the CTE should be a function of temperature and not space. I was wondering whether it is possible to allow the CTE to be position dependent via using ParsedFunc/ParsedAux/ParsedMaterial.
I did try using ParsedMaterial and write the above expression, but it also gave an error, which in my understanding also points to the notion that the ParsedMaterial function should also be dependent on a coupled variable (temperature) instead of space.
In my actual problem I will have a time and space varying temperature field in the body as well as was hoping for a spatially variable CTE.
Please let me know your thoughts, and again any help is greatly appreciated :)
-Aritra

I dont think this is can be done through the input file.
The creators of this object meant to model the influence of temperature. The functions are queried with a temperature argument, not a spatial coordinate.
You can easily adapt the source code to use Z or any function of Z though. So in that way yes it is very possible to allow the CTE to depend on position.
Guillaume
